video_description: Live from MWC 2012 Phonearena presents Asus Transformer Pad Infinity 700 Series Hands-on Review. Coming to market later this year as the ASUS Transformer Pad Infinity 700 series, the tablet with HD display we first saw at CES last month now adds one more key option - a version with 1.5 GHz dual-core Qualcomm Snapdragon S4 and 4G LTE connectivity. For more information check out http://www.phonearena.com/news/Asus-Transformer-Pad-Infinity-700-Hands-on-Review_id27464
title: Asus Transformer Pad Infinity 700 Series Hands-on Review

The best part is the hardware that crushes both tablets. It has an Intel Atom Clover Trail processor at 1.7GHz, 2GB Ram, 64GB SSD (and yes﻿ I mean SSD and not eMMC), and the PowerV SGX544 (as apposed the the SGX543 in the New iPad).

comments.text: Obviously, the hardware on this 'tablet' would crush all other tablets, but I think it would fit better into the category of a 'slate' rather than in the category of a tablet, especially with the Intel Atom﻿ processor.  Furthermore, hardware performance on this slate would be offset by the fact that it would probably be running Windows, which requires more system resources than a mobile OS like Android or iOS.

comments.text: I've used the 3rd gen iPad and it actually looks amazing when using native apps or watching 1080p movies, but the﻿ 4:3 aspect ratio puts me off the screen when it comes to watching videos.  I'd take the 1920x1200 screen of the Infinity over the 3rd gen iPad's 2048x1536 screen simply because of the widescreen aspect ratio.

comments.text: I'm not sure about America, but in Australia, the tablet+dock will sell for AU$899 for﻿ the 64GB WiFi-only version.  In America, the prices are at least $100 less, so I'm guessing that the tablet-only 32GB would sell for around about US$599 maximum, but it could be less.

comments.text: Well, I suppose you can say it has a lot in common with the Fujitsu Stylistic slate except this one is using a CPU that competes more with the voltage of ARM CPUs, but that also means it has less power. The tablet or slate is called the﻿ "ASUS Tablet 810," and it is designed specifically for Windows 8, and while it may be more bloated than both of those the optimization is phenomenal.

comments.text: Asus already has a line of slates, so I'm assuming that this one is just following on from that line. comments.text: Yes, but this﻿ has the third generation Intel Atom so it is slim with no fans. It is a very beautiful sleek device. comments.text: The biggest difference is that it has a much higher resolution than the Transformer Prime.  It's much closer to (but not quite on par with) the New iPad's retina display.  Basically Asus is doing the same thing Apple did with the step up from the iPad 2 to the New iPad.  They also fixed the GPS and Wifi issues that plagued the Transformer Prime by adding﻿ that rubber strip at the top instead of casing the whole tablet in the same metal.  That being said, I will be getting one when this comes out!

comments.text:
I'm going to get the 32G.  I don't have a lot of stuff I'm going to store directly on the device, and Asus has announced that you will get 8G of cloud storage with the purchase of the Infinity, so really you're looking at 40G.  I'll keep large files like movies on an﻿ external source, whether that be a micro SD card (tablet), or external hard drive, usb flash drive, or SD card (keyboard).  

Check out other YouTube videos to see the performance of external sources on the Transformer Prime.
